655 P.2d 526 (1982)
Mayfield Allen KIPER, Appellant,
v.
The STATE of Nevada, Respondent.
No. 13326.
Supreme Court of Nevada.
December 29, 1982.
Morgan D. Harris, Public Defender, and Gary H. Lieberman, Deputy Public Defender, Clark County, Las Vegas, for appellant.
Richard H. Bryan, Atty. Gen., Carson City, Robert J. Miller, Dist. Atty., and James Tufteland, Deputy Dist. Atty., Clark County, Las Vegas, for respondent.

OPINION
PER CURIAM:
Appellant was charged with burglary. At trial, the jury heard testimony from the occupants of a residence that they had been eating breakfast on their front porch when they heard their dog bark. They ran to the back of the house in time to see the appellant rapidly walk out of the bedroom. Upon being asked what he was doing, the appellant replied that he had been looking for "a little short white guy, Mike, who came in." When asked to leave, appellant complied. One of the occupants testified that appellant behaved like "a perfect gentleman." Nothing was taken from the house, and nothing had been disturbed.
Appellant declined to testify at trial. During argument, his attorney conceded that appellant had been in the house but argued that nothing introduced at trial indicated that Kiper entered the house with larcenous intent and that the most appellant was guilty of was criminal trespass.
